Award.AwardTitle: OPTION 1: Small-Business ERC Collaborative Opportunity for the transitioning of agile broadband transmitter for integrated access networks to market

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit

This Small-Business ERC Collaborative Opportunity transitioning agile broadband
transmitter for integrated access networks to market will address the challenge of achieving high
bandwidth (100+ Gb/s), low power, low cost wavelength division multiplexed (WDM) optical
communications links of distances up to 2 km for applications such as data centers and
aggregation networks. These links are necessary for next generation data center and
supercomputing applications that are a focus of the CIAN ERC?s research.
Specifically, this project will improve the lasers in these systems, which drive much of
the cost, performance, and power requirements for the links, to meet current commercial
specifications. The tunable VCSELs offer a 10X reduction in power and cost over conventional
solutions and enable high bandwidth links within data centers that not economically feasible with
current technologies.

Broader Impacts

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is a drastic reduction in the cost
and energy requirements of optical links inside of data centers and supercomputers. Companies
such as Google, Microsoft and other large data-centric companies have been clamoring for this
type of product in the last year to maintain the rate of growth in their data center facilities.
Present WDM laser array solutions using DFB lasers require 10X the power and 10X the cost of
a VCSEL-based approach and are not economically feasible. Present 850-nm VCSEL-based
links, on the other hand, cannot be made into a WDM source without power-hungry TEC coolers
due to their lack of precise, gridded, wavelength control, limiting the overall link speed. Using a
1550 nm tunable VCSEL solves both the problem of gridded wavelength control and allows the
use of low cost single mode fiber and the developed infrastructure for 1550 nm WDM optical
links. The realization of tunable VCSELs in WDM systems will result in a 10X reduction in
both cost and energy requirements in high-speed optical links for data centers, enabling the
further scaling of computational power for next generation data center and supercomputer
applications.

Besides the technological impact, this collaboration program will offer CIAN students
insight and experience with the real world commercial product development process. The
students will be testing and giving feedback into the product development process, enhancing
their educational experience. The enhanced capabilities of the VCSELs will enable new
applications and enhance CIAN in it?s mission of supporting transparency wherever possible
with flexible wavelength conversion and optical switches, and supporting dynamically
reconfigurable heterogeneous traffic in the network.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small-Business ERC Collaborative Opportunity (SECO) project addressed the problem of high bandwidth (10+ Gb/s), low power, low cost, wavelength division multiplexed (WDM) optical communications links of distances up to 20 km for internet access networks (including home and business internet as well as 4G cellular) and data centers. These links are necessary for next generation internet, mobile, cloud, and data center applications.  Specifically, this project examined the lasers, which make up much of the cost and power requirements.  The project addressed the problem by improving an existing low cost, low power laser structure, vertical cavity surface emitting lasers (VCSELs), to be suitable for uncooled WDM operation.  Specifically, this project studied 1550 nm tunable VCSELs, with a goal of taking the tunable VCSEL technology developed under the Center for Integrated Access Networks (CIAN) ERC at UC-Berkeley, and improving the modulation, temperature, and tuning performance of the devices to meet commercial specifications, specifically, direct modulation of the devices at 10 Gbps across a 32 nm tuning range (the optical C-band) and 1 mW output power at 65º C.  

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is a reduction in the cost and energy requirements of optical links used by internet service providers, wireless backhaul links, data centers and supercomputers.  Service providers in particular have been clamoring for this type of product in the last year to maintain the rate of growth in their internet service speeds to homes, businesses, and 4G cellular links.  Present WDM laser array solutions using DFB lasers require 10X the power and 10X the cost of a VCSEL-based approach.  Present 850-nm VCSEL-based links, on the other hand, cannot be made into a WDM source due to their lack of precise, gridded, wavelength control and cannot go distances over a few hundred meters due to their wavelength dispersion.  Using a single mode 1550 nm tunable VCSEL solves both the problem of gridded wavelength control while allowing for link lengths of up to 20 km.  The realization of tunable VCSELs in WDM systems will result in a significant reduction in both cost and energy requirements in high-speed optical links for access networks and data centers, enabling the further scaling of computational power for next generation data center and cloud applications.   

In this SECO program, Bandwidth10 accomplished major technical milestones towards the final goal of realization of a compact 1550 nm tunable-VCSEL.  VCSELs with a 25 nm tuning range were realized as well as VCSELs with 3.5 mW output power.  Directly-modulated VCSELs were realized at 10 Gbps and 1 mW output power at 50º C.  The VCSEL’s thermal, optical, and electrical properties were modeled and optimized for this performance.  Further improvements to reach the final commercialization goals are in progress.
